Change has been successfully merged

21 is the latest approved patch-set.
No files were changed between the latest approved patch-set and the submitted one.

Hi Thu, I think there are some opportunities to clean it up a bit. I've left some comments. The main concern though is that we don't mutate the buffer inside the `span` APIs, that's not what they're for.

Thanks for updating the changelog :) However, the intent is that it's to track changes to the public API/ABI. This way it's easy for users of the library to understand how they're impacted by upgrading. The `msgbuf` APIs are purely internal to the library implementation, users have no visibility of them, hence I'd prefer to not add `msgbuf`-related changes here.
Done
Use [memmem(3)](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/memmem.3.html)?
memmem() required the max size of str pointer. But we are finding that value. So we can't use memmem().
Use `memmem()` and subtract the pointer difference off of `ctx->remaining`?
Done
We've already calculated this haven't we? It's the difference between `(ptr - ctx->cursor) / sizeof(char16_t)`? I'm not yet convinced we need `char16len()`.
Done

Please no. The `msgbuf` `span` APIs should never change data in the buffer, they should only provide a pointer to an opaque byte range inside the buffer. They are a means to advance the `msgbuf` cursor over something we'll decode later.

Any decoding should be left to a different API: UTF16-BE is its own thing, please leave the endianness handling to the string decoding library.
Done
Hi Thu, I have a few minor concerns inline. Hopefully we'll converge a bit once they're addressed.
I don't think we need this now?

Actually we are using this function https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/72547/6/tests/msgbuf.cpp#910 to compare the parsed char16_t string with the expected string.
We can use `required` to replace `sizeof(char16_t) * (char16len(retBuff) + 1)`, But I think in the real case we don't have `required`
Ah, then can you please move this implementation into the test source file that needs it? I'd prefer we don't provide the opportunity to gain users of this in the library implementation.
Done
This one is unnecessary 😊
Huh. That doesn't make any sense to me. Let me experiment with it.
With the updating of pldm_msgbuf_span_string_utf16() API, I removed that line and no more error.
The `assert()` should go below the variable declarations.
Done
I have a mild preference for naming these `len` and `end` respectively.
Done
I don't think we need this, see below.
Done

We can use `u""` here instead of the `terminator` variable. The `u` prefix designates that the string literal should be encoded as a `char16_t`. The empty string always generates a `NUL` terminator, so combined this generates a pointer to the value we're looking for 😊 (a 16-bit 0).
Were there problems with this suggestion?

Add `u""` in the code. The unit-test will auto update the code to 
`u ""` as below. It seems that is the unit-test issue.
So I temporarily keep `uint8_t term[2] = {0x00, 0x00};`

```
diff --git a/src/msgbuf.h b/src/msgbuf.h
index 8b4d571..45c4194 100644
--- a/src/msgbuf.h
+++ b/src/msgbuf.h
@@ -1065,7 +1065,7 @@ pldm_msgbuf_span_string_utf16(struct pldm_msgbuf *ctx, void **cursor)
                return pldm_msgbuf_status(ctx, EINVAL);
        }

-       end = memmem(ctx->cursor, ctx->remaining, u"", sizeof(char16_t));
+       end = memmem(ctx->cursor, ctx->remaining, u "", sizeof(char16_t));
```
Uggghh, of course it does. Okay, no worries.
This can be `sizeof(char16_t)` as with the suggestion above we no-longer need a named variable.
Done

The condition as you've written it is is handled down on line 1084 below.

However, we can re-purpose this by using the condition `ctx->remaining < INTMAX_MIN + (intmax_t)str_size`, with the error being `EOVERFLOW` below. But we also need to ensure that `str_size < INTMAX_MAX` before doing the cast.
Done
This cast should be unnecessary? It may also cause some grief as even _creating_ an unaligned pointer yields undefined behaviour.
Done
Hi Thu, thanks for iterating on this. I have some similar suggestions to the previous patch.
Ah, I think I missed commenting last time that we no-longer need this?
Done
On the `pldm_msgbuf_span_string_ascii()` patch I suggested adding a `size_t *length` argument - can you please do the same here?
Done
... and with the suggestion of the `length` argument, can we rename `str_size` to `measured` for consistency with the `pldm_msgbuf_span_string_ascii()` patch?
Done
Use `u""` and remove `term` from line 1061 above?
In the other comment, you accepted to use term.
The expression suggests `str_size` should be of type `ptrdiff_t`.
Done

Can you drop the extra parentheses here?

```
if (str_size % 2) {
```
Done
Done
No need for this now.
Done
Please use `pldm_msgbuf_init_errno()` throughout, I don't want to see more calls to `pldm_msgbuf_init_cc()` added to the codebase.
Done

`retBuf` is declared `char16_t *`, which means you must obey alignment requirements. Given that we end up pointing into an arbitrary buffer, that's likely problematic. You'll need to change it to `char *`. Please address that concern throughout.
Done
This test was grouped with the other `span_required` tests; can you please fix the ordering so we don't fragment them?
Done

Hi Thu, this largely looks good as well. The two significant comments are really the behaviour of the `length` out-parameter, and the one about adding an assert to enforce alignment before casting to `char16_t *` in the tests.

Ah, so you really made me think with this one 😄

I debated with myself whether we should be providing a "count" here. As further consideration we have the proposed `pldm_msgbuf_extract_array()` behaviour where we do accept a "count" value. However, and I've arrived at the conclusion that we really do want "length" here (equivalent to `sizeof()`), for the following reasons:

1. Because of the lack of alignment constraints in the message buffer, the spanned range of memory cannot immediately be treated as an array of e.g. `char16_t`. It can only be used as blob of bytes (despite the fact that we "know" at a higher-level what type of data is in the span). The only sensible way to measure a blob of bytes is in terms of the number of bytes.

2. The span APIs were always about an "opaque" region of memory. Again, with this context the only useful measure is the number of bytes.

So with these combined can you please just assign `measured` to `length` without the division to account for the type size?
Sure. I updated the code.
maybe `str16len()` given we're measuring the length of the `char16_t` string, and not "`sizeof(char16_t)`"?
Done
As a general note, you'll need to be very careful about alignment with your test case data if you're creating `char16_t` pointers into the message data buffer.
I updated the code to add `ASSERT_EQ(0, (uintptr_t)retBuf & (alignof(char16_t) - 1));` as your suggested.
Done

I'd add `ASSERT_EQ(0, (uintptr_t)retBuf & (alignof(char16_t) - 1));` on the line before just to be on the safe side. That will protect the `char16_t *` cast here.

Check the rest of the tests for any similar cast and add the same assertion where necessary.
Done
This will need to be adjusted in the context of the discussion about the `length` value.
Done
Looks good. Thanks.

Ah, actually, can you make this `sizeof(term)`, just so we're actually reflecting the relevant buffer size? If you're feeling truly paranoid you could add `static_assert(sizeof(term) == sizeof(char16_t));`, but it shouldn't be necessary 😊
Done
Thanks Thu 😊
Do we want to add this entry to the CHANGELOG.md file?
These are internal APIs so we will not add to CHANGELOG.md.
I prefer we say the "the UTF16 string length in terms of bytes, including the NUL terminator"
Done
Can you please put a line-break before the code-block so it's visually separated from the paragraph?
Done
Again, another line-break above here, so it's not so cluttered.
Done
Hi Thu, I have a few nitpicks in the commit message, but I think this is otherwise okay.
